newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Overnight guilders higher as market finds its feet.
newsitem.headline: Overnight guilders higher as market finds its feet.

text.p: Dutch money market players were still finding their feet on Friday after the Dutch central bank introduced a new set of money market instruments, dealers said.
The new range of instruments -- introduced to bring Dutch money market practice into line with other European countries ahead of monetary union -- came into effect today.
"It seems like a busy market, but there's more asking than real trade going on," one dealer said.
"Trade came on stream rather late, as market players first wanted to see what the allocation was like," another said.
The central bank allocated 3.84 billion guilders to the money market this morning, under a new seven-day special advances pact at an unchanged rate of 2.90 percent.
Call money edged higher to trade between 3.25 and 3.75 percent, up from 3.06 percent on Thursday.
"The allocation seems reasonable to me, so I guess the higher overnight rate can be put down to unfamiliarity with the new situation," one dealer said.
Additional paper work linked with the new monetary instruments, causing some parties to have uneven positions, added to upward pressure on call rates, one dealer said.
Dealers said trade focused on call money and deposits up to one month. One month-deposits were quoted at 3.12/20 percent bid/ask, unchanged from Thursday.
The Finance Ministry's Agent no longer gave an indicative price for Dutch Treasury Certificates (DTCs) maturing in June.
"We've reached the maximum amount of 7.5 billion guilders in the June one yesterday, and will not reopen it -- unless we first buy some of it back, which is unlikely," an Agency official said.
Dealers said there had been some brisk business in DTCs on Thursday, notably in the June programme.
The Agent set indicative prices for the July DTC at 3.13 percent, versus 3.17 percent on Thursday.
"We've collected so much this week that, on the short term, we no longer feel the urge to steer the public treasury...these are quite defensive prices," the official said.
"It also depends on what we've already collected under the programme....we often announce a new DTC at the end of the month," he added.
